thread.title: Local roundup: East Lyme beats Law 28-12 for first football win
thread.title_full: Local roundup: East Lyme beats Law 28-12 for first football win

author: Day Staff Reports
title: Local roundup: East Lyme beats Law 28-12 for first football win
text:
Local roundup: East Lyme beats Law 28-12 for first football win Published October 20. 2015 2:38AM Updated October 20. 2015 2:53AM Day Staff Reports 
Milford — Dylan Hatajik ran for one touchdown and passed for a second as East Lyme High School won its first football game of the season with a 28-12 nonleague victory over Law. 
The Vikings (1-4) turned a Law fumble into Hatajik's 3-yard TD run an early 7-0 lead. A 30-yard interception return by Travis Franco with 7 minutes, 53 seconds remaining in the first half upped East Lyme's lead to 14-0, and after Law (0-5) cut the deficit to 14-6 at halftime, the Vikings broke the game open in the second half. 
Ryan Janovic's 15-yard touchdown run, coming on a 4th-and-1, made it 21-6 in the third quarter before Hatajik hooked up with Evan Tryon for an 11-yard TD reception with 6:57 left in the game to make it 28-6. 
H.S. swimming 
• East Lyme wrapped up the ECC title with a 101-76 win over Ledyard. The Vikings (12-1, 9-0) also beat Old Lyme, 106-35. Gretchen Stelter, Maeve Counter, Emma Magna, Jazzy Bazinet, Abigail Bessire and Anneliese Lapides won events for East Lyme. Olivia Strelevitz won the 100-yard butterfly and 100 backstroke for Ledyard (7-4, 6-4), which beat Old Lyme 114-50. Lily cox of Old Lyme won the 500 freestyle. 
• Ashley Lac (200 freestyle), MaKayla Jones (200 IM), Jocelyn McNally (diving) and Macayla Schmidt (100 butterfly) won individual events as Norwich Free Academy defeated Windham/Lyman Memorial 92-68 in the ECC. Jones also teamed up with Kaelan Greene, Eve Buckridge and Madison Lacy to win the 200 medley relay for the Wildcats (4-7, 3-6). 
H.S. volleyball 
• Waterford clinched at least a share of the ECC Medium Division title with a 25-10, 25-12 and 25-14 win over New London. The Lancers (11-4, 6-0) can win the championship outright with a victory at Killingly on Monday. New London is 0-12, 0-6. Alaina Moger had 11 assists, Jill Sykora nine aces and Mickayla Shelburn seven kills for Waterford. 
• Fitch lost its first match of the season, falling to Glastonbury 3-1 in nonleague play. Glastonbury (12-2) won 25-23, 20-25, 25-12, 26-24. Mae Sefransky had 32 assists and Jen Severino had 13 kills for Fitch (14-1). 
• NFA beat Bacon in an ECC Large Division match, 25-8, 25-18, 25-18. Mackenzie Burke had 10 kills and 14 digs, Kate-Lyn Nol had 14 points and seven aces and Kayley Ericson had 36 assists for NFA (7-6, 2-3). 
• Killingly beat Norwich Tech in a nonleague match, 25-10, 25-11, 25-14. Madison Bodley had six kills for Norwich Tech (8-4). 
• Coginchaug beat Old Lyme in a Shoreline Conference match, 13-25, 25-19, 25-4, 25-13. Sophia Romeo had six kills, Laura Lee Wayland had 10 kills and Marissa Smith had eigth assists for Old Lyme. 
• Putnam beat Grasso Tech in the Constitution State Conference, 25-18, 16-25, 25-14, 25-19. Kiera Sebastian had 15 points, Vanessa Parra had six kills and seven digs and Keila Lastraglio had six assists and nine points for Grasso. 
H.S. field hockey 
• Cara Bradley scored three goals as East Lyme beat Fitch/Ledyard in an ECC match, 5-0. Lauren Abbey had a goal and an assist, Kaihley Rafferty and Alexis Burgess scored goals and Amelia Selmeski, Rachael Silva and Kaitlin Kluge had assists for East Lyme (9-2-1, 8-2-1). 
H.S. cross country 
• Williams School finished second in the boys' race and the girls' race at the Rocky Hill School Invitational on Thursday. Will Jarrett of Williams won the boys' race in 18:05 and teammate Colin Madaus was fifth. Mary Madaus was the top girls' finisher for Williams, coming in third, and Hattie Grant was fifth. 
College volleyball 
• Connecticut College won its sixth straight, beating Trinity 25-23, 25-14, 26-28, 25-11 in a New England Small College Athletic Conference match. Jenny Kellogg had 13 kills, five digs and four blocks, Sam Hunter had nine kills and four digs, Caroline Branigan had 22 digs and Caroline Martin had 12 digs for Conn (12-5, 3-4). 
• Endicott scored the final six points in the fifth set and beat Coast Guard 25-21, 23-25, 23-25, 25-18, 15-13. Madison Scott had 17 kills, Susan West had 15 kills and 11 digs, Michelle Gill had 23 digs and Maggie Hine had 51 assists for Coast Guard (13-7).
